item.title: The Accessibility Project
item.description: An Invitation to Join the Accessibility Project Researchers in the Department of Linguistics at Memorial University of Newfoundland, in partnership with the Newfoundland and Labrador Stuttering Association, are launching a new province-wide Accessibility to Services for People Who Stutter Project fo...

item.title: Community Workshops
item.description: Community Workshops Community workshops are a central part of the Accessibility Project.

item.title: Ethics & Values
item.description: Ethics & Values This project is grounded in ethical, collaborative, and justice-oriented research practices.

item.title: Interviews
item.description: Interviews Semi-structured interviews form the second phase of the project.

item.title: Methods Overview
item.description: Methods Overview The Accessibility Project uses a mixed-methods, community-engaged research design.

item.title: Survey
item.description: Survey The project begins with a province-wide survey designed to assess: Access to speech-language pathology services Barriers to participation Experiences in schools, healthcare, and workplaces Community and policy gaps The survey is open to: People who stutter Family members Clinicians Educators ...

item.title: What This Project Is
item.description: What This Project Is The Accessibility Project is a multi-stage research and community-engagement initiative focused on identifying and removing barriers to full participation for people who stutter (PWS) in Newfoundland and Labrador.

item.title: Who We Are
item.description: Who We Are This project is a collaboration among: People who stutter (PWS) Newfoundland and Labrador Stuttering Association (NLSA) Memorial University of Newfoundland (MUN) Educators, clinicians, policymakers, and community allies Our team is committed to ethical, community-engaged, and accessible r...

item.title: Why Accessibility Matters in NL
item.description: Why Accessibility Matters in Newfoundland and Labrador People who stutter (PWS) often face structural, communicative, and attitudinal barriers across health services, schools, workplaces, and public life.

item.title: Declaration of the Right to Stutter
item.description: We, the undersigned, declare that people who stutter should be accepted as having a stutter.
